questions.question: The police are searching for the man ………………………… abducted the child.
questions.description: Use who to refer to people and which to refer to things.

questions.question: This is the book ………………………….. I was talking about.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Do you know anyone ………………………. can repair my camera?
The jewels ……………………….. the heiress wore were very expensive.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: The flowers ………………………… adorn the dais are artificial.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: The athlete ………………………… ankle was broken might need surgery.
questions.description: Whose can refer to both people and things. Use it to replace pronouns in the possessive case.

questions.question: The parrot …………………………. wings are broken may not fly ever again.
The clown ……………………….. antics amused everyone was not happy in his life.
The microwave oven …………………………… I bought for Christmas was not very expensive.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Athletes ………………………… practice everyday are more likely to win.
This is the house …………………………..  I inherited from my grandfather.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: The lion killed the deer ………………………….. was drinking water from the stream.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Do you know the man ……………………….. called this morning?
questions.description: Use who to refer to people. The relative pronoun who acts as the subject of the relative clause.

questions.question: I know a child ………………………. can do complex math in her head.
questions.description: Use who to refer to people. The relative pronoun who acts as the subject of the relative clause.

questions.question: Maria ………………………… parents are rich considers herself above us.
questions.description:
The relative pronoun whose replaces pronouns like his, her or their.
Maria considers herself above us. Her parents are rich. Maria whose parents are rich considers herself above us.

questions.question: It was a puzzle …………………………. no one could solve.
The man ……………………….. legs were amputated can never walk again.
The girl ………………………….. he is going to marry is an old friend of mine.
questions.description: That can replace whom in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: The police arrested the man …………………………. rants on social media led to a communal clash.
The girl ………………………… parents work abroad lives with her grandmother.
He has bought a parrot ……………………….. can speak.
This is the estate ………………………. I inherited from my grandfather.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things.

questions.question: The birds …………………………. were kept in the cage were released by the man.
All ………………………….. I have is yours.
The know the man ……………………….. filed the complaint.
questions.description: Use who to refer to people.

questions.question: This is the boy ………………………….. I was talking about.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses that can be used instead of whom.

questions.question: I know a woman ………………………….. sells spices in the market.
questions.description: Use who to refer to people.

questions.question: It was a question …………………………. no one could answer.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, either which or that can refer to things, ideas etc.

questions.question: The plants ………………………….. I bought from the nursery last week have died.
The woman ………………………… knee was broken required surgery.
questions.description: The woman required surgery. Her knee was broken. We use whose in the place of possessive adjectives like his, her, their etc. The woman whose knee was broken required surgery.

questions.question: The child ……………………….. parents had died now lives in an orphanage.
The flowers ………………………….. were used to decorate the stage were not real.
questions.description: Either that or which is possible here.

questions.question: The parrot ………………………….. I have been keeping for a while can speak a few words.
The boys ……………………………. have been selected for the team are practicing in the stadium.
This is the house …………………………..  I bought from my uncle.
The man released the birds ………………………….. were kept in a cage.
questions.description: Either which or that can refer to things, animals etc in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: This is the new laptop ……………………… my father bought yesterday.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, either that or which can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: The village ……………………….. we live is infested with rats.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: We live in an old house ………………………….. is infested with rats.
questions.description: Either which or that is possible here.

questions.question: The Taj Mahal, ……………………….. is the finest tomb in the world, is built by Shah Jahan.
questions.description: We cannot use that in non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Pinki, ………………………. father is a native of Mumbai, speaks both Hindi and Marathi fluently.
questions.description: Whose replaces pronouns like his, her or their.

questions.question: This is my brother …………………………. you met yesterday.
questions.description: Who is also possible here in a less careful style.

questions.question: Twinkle, ………………………… I want to meet, is my cousin.
His sister knows the place ………………………… he keeps his money.
questions.description: Where can mean at which.

questions.question: The school ……………………….. my brother worked for five years is the only school on the island.
Napoleon, ……………………….. the French honor, died at St. Helena.
The boy ………………………….. was not paying attention in the class was reprimanded by the teacher.
The man ………………………… lives next door is very friendly.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who, not whom.

questions.question: The man ……………………………. we met in the store is my neighbor.
questions.description: Whom and that are possible here. Who is also possible here in a less careful style.

questions.question: The girl …………………………….. paid for my drinks seemed rich.
questions.description: Either who or that can refer to people in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Where is the child ……………………………… wanted an ice cream?
questions.description: Use who to refer to people and which to refer to things.

questions.question: I have lost the watch …………………………… I bought yesterday.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses either which or that can refer to things.

questions.question: The day …………………………….. my son was born is the happiest day of my life.
questions.description: When can mean on which.

questions.question: The man ……………………….. interviewed me was very knowledgeable.
He has four cars all of …………………………… are imported.
I talked to the guy …………………………… repaired my computer.
The man ………………………………. died in the accident was a rich merchant.
The police arrested the man ……………………………. made the hoax call.
The boy ………………………….. leg is broken will need complete bed rest for at least six months.
questions.description: Whose can replace pronouns like his, her, their etc.

questions.question: The girl ……………………………. opened the door was quite cute.
questions.description: Either who or that is possible here.

questions.question: He sold the land …………………….. belonged to his brother.
questions.description: Which is used to refer to things. That can also refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: I have no horse …………………….. I can lend you.
questions.description: That can refer to both people and things. It is more common than which after words like no, all, any etc.

questions.question: The marks ………………………… were left by the whip were still visible.
questions.description: Which is used to refer to things. That can also refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: He died in the house ……………………….. he was born.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: Those ………………………… are healthy do not need any physician.
questions.description: Who refers to people.

questions.question: We were accosted by a young girl …………………………. was a tourist guide.
questions.description: Who refers to people.

questions.question: The camel ………………………… I bought from the merchant is old.
questions.description: Which is used to refer to things. That can also refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: I can’t stand the stench ……………………….. comes from this drain.
I saw a man ………………………… was blind.
I found the key ………………………… I had lost.
questions.description: Which is used to refer to things. That can also refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: A castle ………………………….. is built on a hill cannot be hid.
A man ………………………… is industrious is sure to succeed.
The man ………………………. lives next door is an artist.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: Everyone congratulated the boy …………………………. had won the first prize.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: Where is the person ........................................ wanted to meet the manager?
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: We bought some mangoes from ………………………… we extracted the juice.
questions.description: In relative clauses which is used to refer to inanimate objects.

questions.question: She is the only politician ……………………….. I really admire.
questions.description: Here the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause hence we use whom.

questions.question: The woman .................................... diamonds had been stolen complained to the police.
questions.description: In relative clauses whose replaces words like her or his.

questions.question: I know a girl ……………………….. eyes are as deep as the ocean.
questions.description: In relative clauses whose replaces words like her or his.

questions.question: The man .................................... sits in that corner is a writer.
Who is that girl ………………………… danced with your brother?
I talked to the boy ………………………….. everyone seemed to ignore.
The used car …………………………. I bought last week is not very fuel efficient.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses either that or which can be used to refer to objects.

questions.question: The man …………………………. they labelled traitor is actually a patriot.
The boy ………………………. sits there is my cousin.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: The woman ……………………….. opened the door asked us to leave.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: The police arrested the man ………………………… had stolen the bicycle.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: We bought some mangoes from …………………………. we extracted the juice.
questions.description: In relative clauses which is used to refer to inanimate objects.

questions.question: She was a pretty woman ………………………….. everyone seemed to admire.
questions.description: Here the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause hence we use whom.

questions.question: The man ………………………….. car had been stolen called the police.
questions.description: In relative clauses whose replaces words like her or his.

questions.question: I know a girl ........................................ father is a sailor.
questions.description: In relative clauses whose replaces words like her or his.

questions.question: The child …………………………… parents are dead lives in foster care.
Who is that girl ……………………………… is dancing with Sam?
There I met a man ……………………………. seemed to know everything.
Uneasy lies the head …………………………………. wears the crown.
He is a singer …………………………… enjoys considerable fan-following all over the world.
The people ............................... walked in just now seem to be rich.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: The girl ...................................... answered the phone seemed rather clueless.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: Where is the person ........................................ called the police?
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: I have lost the paper on ...................................... I had written her address.
questions.description: In relative clauses which is used to refer to inanimate objects.

questions.question: She is the woman ...................................... I have always wanted to marry.
questions.description: Here the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause hence we use whom.

questions.question: The woman .................................... child had gone missing was frantic.
questions.description: In relative clauses whose replaces words like her or his.

questions.question: I know a girl ........................................ father is an artist.
questions.description: In relative clauses whose replaces words like her or his.

questions.question: The man .................................... bag was stolen complained to the police.
Who is that girl ..................................... is sitting beside James?
I talked to a man ......................................... had just returned from an overseas trip.
He ....................................... has nothing to lose has no worries.
The woman ....................................... you can see over there is my cousin.
The girl .................................... answered the phone was quite polite.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people and which to refer to things. When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who.

questions.question: The woman ...................................... lives next door is an artist.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people and which to refer to things. When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who.

questions.question: Where is the man ...................................... ordered the cab?
questions.description: We use who to refer to people and which to refer to things. When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who.

questions.question: I have lost the paper on ...................................... I had written his address.
The day ............................................ I met her is the happiest day of my life.
questions.description: When can mean on which.

questions.question: The man .............................................. interviewed me was quite helpful.
questions.description: That can refer to people in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: I have got four dogs all of ................................................... are quite friendly.
You should talk to the people ........................................... placed this order.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people and which to refer to things. When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who.

questions.question: The driver ....................................... caused the accident was arrested.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people and which to refer to things. When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who.

questions.question: The police arrested the man ......................................... had stolen the jewels.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people and which to refer to things. When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who.

questions.question: The boy ....................................... leg is broken is sitting there.
I help those ………………………. I love.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause we use whom.

questions.question: He …………………….. works hard will certainly succeed.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: The man ……………………………. has no music in his soul should be tried for treason.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both who and that can refer to people.

questions.question: I have received the message …………………………. you sent me.
questions.description: That and which can both refer to things.

questions.question: Servants …………………………. are honest are trusted.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both who and that can refer to people.

questions.question: He failed in every project ………………………… he started.
He laughs best …………………………. laughs last.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause we use who to refer to people.

questions.question: They never fail ……………………………. die for a good cause.
He …………………………. is down need fear no fall.
This is the bicycle …………………………. I bought for my son.
He is an accomplished singer ………………………. I admire.
I know a man ………………………….. son is an activist.
questions.description: The relative pronoun whose replaces the personal pronouns his, her or their.

questions.question: There was not a child in the class ……………………… did not weep.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: Uneasy lies the head ……………………… wears the crown.
He is a writer ………………………….. I like.
questions.description: When the relative pronoun is the object of the verb in the relative clause we use whom.

questions.question: The house ………………………….. the fire broke out was completely destroyed.
The reason ……………………………… they parted ways is unclear.
He is the boy ………………………… won the first prize.
He released the bird ………………………… flew away at once.
questions.description: We use which to refer to things, animals, birds etc.

questions.question: On the day ………………………… he was born, I was the happiest mother in the world.
Give me something ………………………….. I may eat.
questions.description: That is more common than which after something, anything, everything.

questions.question: I have duties …………………………. I must perform.
Childhood is the time ………………………….. the seeds of character are sown.
You can hardly expect any good work from men …………………………… are great boasters.
The village ................................ I was born is a few hundred miles from here.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: This is the store in ................................ I used to work.
questions.description: In which is similar to where. We cannot use that after a preposition.

questions.question: He was admired by the people with ............................... he worked.
questions.description: In a formal style, the preposition comes before the relative pronoun.

questions.question: He was loved by the people ................................. he worked with.
questions.description: In an informal style, the preposition goes at the end of the sentence.

questions.question: This is the room .................................... I was born in.
questions.description: That is used when the preposition goes at the end. It cannot be used after a preposition.

questions.question: Do you know ................................ country she is from?
He always quarreled with the people with ................................... he worked.
questions.description: We cannot use who and that after prepositions.

questions.question: Do you know …………………………. I met at the club yesterday?
questions.description: In an informal style who is also possible here.

questions.question: ………………………….. she said made me angry.
questions.description: What means the things which.

questions.question: You should give me …………………………. I want.
questions.description: What means the things which.

questions.question: I know the place …………………….. he lives.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses we get:
I know the place. He lives there.
The relative pronoun where replaces place words like there.

questions.question: He is the man ……………………….. rescued my sister.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses we get:
He is the man. He rescued my sister.
The relative pronoun who replaces words like he, she and they.

questions.question: He never does anything ………………………….. is silly.
questions.description: The relative pronoun that is preferred after words like all, any or anything.

questions.question: Here is the book …………………….. you want.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses we get:
Here is the book. You want it.
The relative pronoun that can replace words like he, she and it.

questions.question: People ………………………. live in glass houses should not throw stones.
questions.description: The relative pronoun who is used to talk about people.

questions.question: Any student ………………………… fails to do the homework will be punished.
He laughs best ……………………….. laughs last.
This is the reason ………………………… he came late.
questions.description: We can use that or why after reason.

questions.question: The explanation …………………………. he gave us was not satisfactory.
The houses in …………………………… the Burmese live are generally built of bamboo.
He met a girl ……………………….. eyes were blue.
questions.description: The relative pronoun whose replaces words like his or her.

questions.question: The author lives in that cottage ……………………….. overlooks the lake.
questions.description: That and which can both refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: It was my manager …………………… sent the parcel to James yesterday.
questions.description: In structures like these we can use the relative pronoun who or that to refer to a personal subject.

questions.question: It was the parcel …………………………. my brother sent to James yesterday.
questions.description: Who cannot be used to refer to an object.

questions.question: It is he …………………………. responsible.
questions.description: In a formal style we use subject pronoun + who + verb in this structure.

questions.question: It is me ………………………… responsible.
questions.description: In an informal style we use ‘that + primary auxiliary’.

questions.question: It is you ………………………. in the wrong.
questions.description: In an informal style ‘that is’ is also possible here.

questions.question: ……………………….. you need is rest.
questions.description: All that can mean what.

questions.question: ……………………. I did was to touch the vase, and it broke.
questions.description: All that can mean what.

questions.question: ………………………… where we live.
The reason ………………………… I went to London was to see my cousin.
questions.description: Reason can be followed by why or that.

questions.question: We moved to the countryside so that the children would have a garden …………………….
questions.description: In a less formal style we can use the infinitive + preposition instead of a relative pronoun.

questions.question: She was miserable unless she had people ……………………………….
questions.description: In a less formal style we can use the infinitive + preposition instead of a relative pronoun.

questions.question: Who is that girl …………………………. next to Peter?

exercises.title: Relative Pronouns Which, That, Where And Whose

questions.question: This is the road ………………………….. takes you to the railway station.
questions.description:
When we split we get: 
This is the road.
It takes you to the railway station.
The relative pronouns which and that can replace the pronoun ‘it’.
In identifying relative clauses, either which or that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: These are some pencils ……………………….. for drawing.
questions.description: Reduced relative clauses are often used with adjectives.

questions.question: The oranges ……………………………. you gave me yesterday were very sweet.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, either which or that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: The Taj Mahal …………………………… was built by Shah Jahan is the finest tomb in the world.
questions.description: In non-identifying relative clauses, that cannot be used here.

questions.question: On this map show me the small island …………………………. is to the south of India.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, either which or that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: This is the new radio …………………………… my father bought yesterday.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, either which or that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: Nobody knows the place …………………………….. he keeps his money.
questions.description:
When we split we get:
Nobody knows the place.
He keeps his money there.
The relative pronoun ‘where’ replaces words like there and here.

questions.question: The school ……………………………. my brother teaches is the only school in this island.
questions.description:
When we split we get:
This is the only school in this island. My brother teaches there.
The relative pronoun ‘where’ replaces words like there and here.

questions.question: The boy ………………………… watch had been stolen complained to the teacher.
questions.description: The boy complained to the teacher. His watch had been stolen. The relative pronoun whose replaces the pronouns his, their, her etc.

questions.question: Jennifer …………………………. father is a native of Germany speaks both German and English fluently.
questions.description:
Jennifer speaks both German and English fluently.
Her father is a native of Germany.
The relative pronoun whose replaces the pronouns his, their, her etc.

questions.question: This is the spot ………………………… I left my car.
questions.description: The relative pronoun ‘where’ replaces words like there and here.

questions.question: This is the field ………………………….. the  battle was fought.
The crow dropped the piece of cheese ………………………. the fox snapped up immediately.
questions.description: We use which to refer to things.

questions.question: People …………………....…. live in glass houses must not throw stones.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both who and that can be used to refer to people.

questions.question: Last year we visited the Leaning Tower of Pisa …………………….. is a great architectural marvel.
questions.description: In non-identifying relative clauses, we cannot use that. A non-identifying relative clause merely provides additional information. It does not identify its antecedent.

questions.question: Where is the book ……………………… I left here yesterday?
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both which and that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: It was a wretched hut ……………………….. she lived.
questions.description:
When we separate these two clauses, we get: it was a wretched hut she lived in it.
When we combine them we replace the prepositional phrase ‘in it’ with ‘in which’.

questions.question: Napoleon, ……………………… the French admire, was a great General.
questions.description: Napoleon was a great General. The French admire him. We need ‘whom’ to replace ‘him’.

questions.question: The boys gave a loud shout ………………………. was heard across the park.
questions.description: We use which to refer to things and ideas.

questions.question: The conference ………………….. was held at a Five Star hotel was a huge success.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both which and that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: The boy spoke to the soldier …………………….. arm was in a sling.
questions.description: When we separate the clauses, we get: the boy spoke to the soldier his arm was in a sling. To replace ‘his’ we use ‘whose’.

questions.question: The captain praised Martin, …………………. bowling was very good.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses, we get:
The captain praised Martin.
His bowling was very good.
To replace ‘his’ we use ‘whose’.

questions.question: James, ……………………… is my cousin, is a pilot.
questions.description: In non-identifying relative clauses, we cannot use that. A non-identifying relative clause merely provides additional information. It does not identify the antecedent.

questions.question: That girl ……………………… you see there sings very well.
questions.description: The girl sings very well. You see her there. To replace 'her' we use 'whom'.

questions.question: Have you got a novel …………………………. is really interesting to read?
questions.description: ‘That’ is possible in this case. ‘That’ can be used to refer to people and things in identifying relative clauses. An identifying relative clause introduces information that cannot be easily left out. ‘Which’ is possible in this case. ‘Which’ can be used to refer to things in both identifying and non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: She has acted in a movie ……………………….. name I have forgotten.
questions.description: 'Whose' is a possessive relative word, used to refer to both people and things. It can replace possessive relative pronouns 'his / her / its'.

questions.question: He is married to a writer ………………………….. you may have heard.
questions.description: Note that the preposition always goes before ‘whom’. We can’t say: He is married to a writer whom you may have heard of.

questions.question: It was a meeting ……………………………. purpose I did not understand.
questions.description: Let's split the sentence into two. It was a meeting. I did not understand its purpose. When we combine these two sentences together, the relative pronoun should replace the pronoun 'its'. Since 'its' is in the possessive case, we need to use a possessive relative pronoun.

questions.question: We became friendly with some students ………………………… we met on the train.
questions.description: We became friendly with some students. We met them on the train. When we combine these two clauses into one, the relative pronoun should replace the object pronoun ‘them’. As you know, ‘who’ is in the nominative case. It is not possible here. Hence, we use ‘whom’. ‘That’ is also possible.We became friendly with some students whom we met on the train. OR We became friendly with some students that we met on the train.

questions.question: Alice married her boyfriend, ……………………......… made her parents very unhappy.
questions.description: The relative pronoun ‘which’ can refer to an entire clause that comes before it.

questions.question: Mary, ………………………… teaches my daughter English, has moved to another city.
questions.description: Here the relative clause is not identifying. It does not identify the person Maya. She has already been identified by her name. ‘That’ cannot be used in non-identifying relative clauses. Therefore, we use who here.

questions.question: I know a shop ……………………….. they sell imported perfumes.
questions.description: ‘Where’ can be used to introduce relative clauses after nouns referring to place. The sentence ‘I know a shop where they sell imported perfumes’ means the same as ‘I know a shop at which they sell imported perfumes’.

questions.question: It is the best film ……………………………… has ever been made about the French Revolution.
questions.description: After superlatives, we use ‘that’, not ‘which’.

questions.question: I have got something .......................................... belongs to you?
questions.description: After quantifiers like all, every, everything, some, something, any, anything, nothing, some, little, few, much and only `that` is more common than `which`.

questions.question: I have got ................................................. I need.
questions.description: In modern English, we use 'what' instead of 'that which'. in this case 'what' means something like 'all that'

questions.question: He was respected by the people with ………………………….. he worked.
questions.description: We require a relative pronoun in the objective case here.

exercises.title: The Relative Pronouns Who, Whom, That, Where, And Which

questions.question: This is the town ...................... I spent my childhood.
questions.description: The relative adverb where can mean in which.

questions.question: This is the town in .................... I spent my childhood.
questions.description: In which means the same as where.

questions.question: This is the house .................... I was born in.
Here is an article ..................... might interest you.
questions.description: The relative pronoun not only connects two clauses but also acts as the subject or object of the verb in the relative clause. As subjects or objects, they replace words like they, them, she, her etc.

questions.question: I gave her a bag ......................... she put in her bag at once.
questions.description: The relative pronoun not only connects two clauses but also acts as the subject or object of the verb in the relative clause. As subjects or objects, they replace words like they, them, she, her etc.

questions.question: This is Alice ........................... you met last year.
questions.description: That can be used to refer to both people and things however, that is not used in non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: I was impressed by the way ............................ she did it.
They got divorced a few months later ............................ surprised nobody.
questions.description: Which can refer to the clause of a previous clause.

questions.question: The people ......................... live next door are not very friendly.
questions.description: Both who and that can refer to people in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: The only thing ................. matters is to find our way home.
questions.description: The relative pronoun that is preferred after words like few, little, only and much.

questions.question: The woman ............................. I marry should have good sense of humor.
questions.description: In an informal style, who can be used as the object of the relative clause.

questions.question: She was loved by the people with .............................. she worked.
questions.description: The relative pronouns who and that are not used after prepositions.

questions.question: I know a man ………………….. son studies in the US.
questions.description: The relative pronoun whose can connect two clauses and replace possessive pronouns like his, her or their.

questions.question: The thief ………………… stole the watch was punished.
questions.description: Which can only be used to refer to things. Whom is an object pronoun.

questions.question: Show me the road ………………. leads to Agra.
questions.description: Both that and which can refer to things.

questions.question: He …………….. does his best should be rewarded.
questions.description: When we split the clauses we get the following: He does his best. He should be rewarded. The relative pronoun 'who' can connect two clauses and replace pronouns like he, she and they.

questions.question: My grandfather ………………. I loved is dead.
questions.description: Whom is the correct option here. Who is also possible in an informal style.

questions.question: Wellington ………………. defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo was a great general.
We met a child ……………. had lost his way.
He is a rascal ……………… no one likes.
questions.description:
When we split the clauses we get the following: He is a rascal. No one likes him. 
The relative pronoun ‘whom’ replaces words like him, her and them.

questions.question: That boy ……………… you see over there plays very well.
questions.description:
When we split the clauses we get: That boy plays very well. You see him over there.
The relative pronoun ‘whom’ replaces words like him, her and them. 'Who' is also possible here in an informal style.

questions.question: Here are the keys ………………. you were looking for.
questions.description: Both 'that' and 'which' can refer to things.

questions.question: The dog bit the burglar ……………….. had broken into the house.
questions.description: When we split the clauses we get the following: The dog bit the burglar. He had broken into the house. The relative pronoun who replaces words like he, she and they.

questions.question: Coal ……………… is a useful mineral is found in many parts of the world.
questions.description:
When we split the clauses we get the following: Coal is a useful mineral. It is found in many parts of the world.
The relative pronoun ‘which’ replaces pronouns like it.

questions.question: He was loved and respected by the people ...................................
questions.description: Prepositions can come either before relative pronouns or at the end of relative clauses.

questions.question: This is the house .............................. I was born.
questions.description: In relative clauses 'where' can be used instead of 'in which'.

questions.question: In that year she met James, ....................... she was later to marry.
questions.description: Whom is the correct option here, but who is also possible in an informal style.

questions.question: Is this all ........................... is left?
questions.description: After quantifiers like all, every, some and any, we prefer 'that' to 'which'.

questions.question: It is the best film ................................ has ever been made about dementia.
questions.description: After superlatives, we prefer 'that' to 'which'.

questions.question: All ............................. you say is true.
questions.description: What cannot be used instead of that.

questions.question: I saw a girl .................................. beauty took my breath away.
questions.description: Whose is a relative possessive word used before nouns in the same way as his, her, its or their.

questions.question: He has launched a business .....................………. I have forgotten.
questions.description: Instead of whose, we can use of which

questions.question: ..................... she said made me angry.
questions.description: What means the things which.

questions.question: The only thing ……………….. keeps me awake is coffee.
questions.description: 'What' can only be used to mean ‘the things which’.

questions.question: We have …………………. we need.
questions.description: That which is possible here but it is unusual in modern English.

questions.question: He got married again a few months later, ..................... .. surprised everybody.
questions.description: Which can refer to the whole of a relative clause.

questions.question: The book ………………… you gave me was interesting.
The boy ………………….. stood first in our class is my friend.
Give me the books …………………. you borrowed from my brother.
I know the man ...................... daughter won the first rank.
John is the guy ...................... helped me when I was in trouble.
I consoled the man …………………. wife had been killed in the accident.
The plants ………………… grow on the mountains look lovely.
This is the only story in this book ………………….. is worth reading.
I saw a girl ………………….. beauty took my breath away.
The boy ...................... I spoke to is my classmate.
This is Jane ——————– works with my sister.
The boy ———————— watch had been stolen complained to the police.
Mary had a little lamb ———————- fleece was as white as snow.
The house ———————- I live is very small.
The castle ———————– stands on the hill is 500 years old.
Do you know the man ———————– just walked in?
He ———————– laughs last laughs best.
I have got the books ———————– you were looking for.
Do you know the reason ————————- she hates me?
This is the road ————————- leads to the temple.
Have you ever spoken to the lady …………………. lives next door?
Those …………………. have not registered should do so at once.
There is a program on TV ……………….. might interest you.
Here are the books ………………… you were looking for.
What’s the name of the fat boy …………………. just walked in?
questions.description: Either who or that is possible here.

questions.question: It is a story ………………… will interest readers of all ages.
The people ……………………… live next door are very annoying.
This is Mr James ………………….. you met last year.
questions.description: Who is possible here in an informal style.

questions.question: Where is the camera …………………. I lent you?
Yesterday I met Nancy ………………… works with my sister.
This is the church .............................. was built in the 16th century.
John .................................. is very industrious was rewarded.
The parcel ..................................... was sent by my mother reached me this morning.
Mark ........................................ is always late for work was reprimanded by his boss.
I met my uncle ........................................ had just returned from the US.
This is the house ........................................ my grandfather built.
The girls ............................................ I was speaking of have arrived.
I know a man ......................................... wears a prosthetic leg.
I talked to the man ………………… bag was stolen.
I don’t know ………………… he wants.
It is an ill wind ……………….. blows nobody good.
God helps those ………………… help themselves.
Please try to understand ……………… I mean.
The flowers ………………….. grow on the mountains are very beautiful.
This is the only chapter in the book ………………… is worth reading.
All …………….. you say is certainly true.
He …………….. dies for a noble cause lives forever.
I hope the little ………………… I have done has been useful.
We moved to the countryside so that our kids would have a garden in ………………….. to play.
She may have missed her train, …………………. case we ought to wait for her.
He got married again two months later, …………………. surprised everybody.
I was impressed by the way …………………. she did it.
This is the house …………………. I was born in.
Do you think you can give me ………………….. I need?
We have got everything …………………. we ordered.
He lost his cool, ………………… point I left for home.
We tested hundreds of jackets none of ………………… was completely waterproof.
Come and see us anytime ………………… you are free.
He got addicted to gambling, …………………… surprised nobody.
I know a girl ………………… mother runs a beauty parlor.
I will never forget the day …………………. I first met him.
Do you know a shop ………………….. I can buy cameras?
Is that your car ………………….. is parked outside?
I don’t know the reason …………………. she doesn’t like me.
I have a friend ………………… works in a pub.
I know a man …………………………….. has just been to Australia.
Show me the road ………………………. leads to the railway station.
Here is the doctor …………………………. cured me of Typhoid.
He…………………………. does his best should be rewarded.
Wellington, …………………………. defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo, was a great general.
He is a rascal ………………………….. no one trusts.
The boy ……………………………… you saw yesterday is my nephew.
The man ………………………………… stole the money has been arrested.
This is the house………………………… was built in two weeks.
The news ……………………………… I heard astonished me.
Do you know …………………………. has happened?
He always preaches …………………………………….. he never practices.
Where is the book …………………………………… I lent you?
He has no sword with ………………………………. to fight.
Where is the man ………………………………….. purse was lost?
I met a man …………………………………… had just returned from America.
Only he …………………………………. wears the shoe knows where it pinches.
This is the house ………………………………. my grandfather built.
The spectators applauded the batsman ……………………………………. performance was spectacular.
……………………………………. the gods love die young.
Have you got anything ............................... belongs to me?
This is Mr. Mathews, ................................ is joining us next week.
Ruth, .................................. does my hair, has moved to another hairdresser’s.
I hope the little .................................. I have done has been useful.
He got married a year later, ................................. surprised everybody.
What is the name of the fat woman ................................ just came in?
The idea ................................ she put forward was interesting.
I met a man ................................... had just returned from France.
The books .................................. you read are not worth reading.
Only he .................................... wears the shoes knows where it pinches.
The audience applauded Mary .................................... performance was spectacular.
John, ........................................ is always mischievous, was punished.
Kochi, ........................................... has a natural harbor, can handle large ships.
He is a writer ....................................... works are well-known.
This is the man .................................. house was burgled.
